Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Zero-UI: Translation of Purdue Gesture-based Creative Interaction Technologies into the Real World
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the last 30 years, use of computers to initially make 2D drawings and sketches, and then to design 3D shapes, have lead to deep research and plethora of geometric and graphic design tools. An analysis of past work reveals that applications are limited by (1) use of 2D input devices such as mouse, keyboard, touch screen, etc. (2) and the limitations of corresponding procedural programs and user interfaces that map user input to computational procedures, and (3) inability to sense, feel and interact with these virtual data and shapes. The current state of unnatural user interactions severely limits the creative expression and manipulation of shapes. It urges us to develop new forms of human machine interaction to unleash the creativity of the mind's eye. The team's vision is to enable a new class of natural user interaction driven shape creation and manipulation paradigms. The team's approach will completely eliminate traditional user interfaces since users will be able to directly interact with 3D content using hand and body. This vision is based on a recent set of our discoveries, enabled by prior NSF support on natural sketch-based interfaces and shape analysis that resulted in the foundation for commercialization.

The science of natural user interfaces and interactions are at a very early stage of development. Highly-digitized user interfaces using windows, icons, mouse and pointer have resulted in overlooking the role of the user in creative interaction with virtual shapes. The team's work contributes and creates new ways in which users will interact with geometric data spaces. Areas of scientific inquiry we will contribute to include human-computer interaction, machine learning, gesture-based interaction, and ubiquitous computing. Gesture based natural user interfaces (NUI) enabled by 3D sensing cameras are the next frontier in computing, media and entertainment and other verticals. This work can result in new capabilities in edutainment and game design, training technologies, haptic interfaces for disabled, interactive advertising, personal manufacturing and many other applications not yet imagined.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Purdue University and ZeroUI have co-developed a gesture based 3D shape modeling technology that leverages 3D depth sensors such as Microsoft Kinect. We applied to ICorps program to develop a commercialization plan for this technology innovation.

 

Prior to ICORPS, our hypothesis was that our technology was best suited to develop Xbox Kinect games for kids that are 5 to 12 years old. Following the game development, we believed a suitable follow up product would be developing a software developer kit (SDK) so many developers could utilize our technology.

 

ICorps helped us validate this hypothesis with kids and their parents for the games and developers for the SDK product. But ICorps teachers encouraged us to think broader and find other potential customers segments by widening our search. This led us to identify future customer segments in 3D designers, artists, engineers, animators that could all benefit from our 3D modeling technology with hands free interface.

 

With the limitations of the current 3D sensing technologies, we decided the gaming market and SDK development would be the best route for us to enter a large market and establish our footholds. Then when the hardware becomes more advanced and ubiquitous, pivot and enter the utility markets for artists, designers, and engineers.

 

Focusing on video game and SDK sales, we were able to identify the sales models for games and SDK products. Video game sales fit with the indirect sales model, and SDK sales fit with the direct sales model.

 

In conjunction with the channel economics, relevant sales channels were also identified based on interviews with people inside the gaming industry. We learned that there are two main channels to sell video games. The traditional method resides with physical game sales. Physical game sales are selling a game via a physical disc, either through a brick and mortar sales front, or an online source such as Amazon. A more recent sales channel is through an application store front, or an App Store.

 

Physical game sales begin with the platform and developer. The Publisher handles marketing and distributing to the Retailer. The Retailer then is responsible for the physical sale of the video game.

 

In the direct sales model for  we sell the SDK as a downloaded product from our company website. Through interviews with developers, we learned that they would rather be able to purchase and download an SDK through the company’s website and simply pay through credit card. With this sales model, we would need to set up a customer support and also a forum online for people to discuss and trouble shoot.

 

As a game developer with the indirect sales channel, we don’t acquire direct marketing costs associated with the physical video game. However, as a developer we must market our company at trade events. This means we must field a business development team to attend the trade shows and foster relationships inside the industry.

 

Marketing the SDK in the direct sales channel requires full get, keep, and grow cycle.  We acquire customers using PR and building relations with developers at tradeshows. We would also gain attention through free media channels via conferences, speeches, journal publications, and blogs. We offer trial versions to be downloaded on our website for developers to try before they buy. We retain customers with quality customer service and constant product improvements. We can grow these customers by up-selling, cross-selling and referral sales.
